K. DAS, Acting Chief Justice--This is an appeal by special leave. The appellant is a member of the Indian Police Service.
This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment of the High Court of Punjab dismissing the appellants writ petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the order of reversion violated Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: the order of reversion was malafide, improper and against the provisions of Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution. On behalf of the respondents, the main contention has been that under the relevant rules the appellant

arguments.claim: Under relevant rules, member of IPS entitled as of right to promotion to senior scale post when vacancy arises (except promotion quota) and no senior available; reversion is reduction in rank under Art 311(2) without opportunity.

anchor.surface_text: The principal contention of the appellant has been that under the relevant rules governing the Indian Police Service, a member thereof is entitled as of right to be promoted to a post in the senior scale as and when a vacancy  except a vacancy in the promotion quota  arises therein and noone senior to him is available for that post at the time when the appellant was reverted, officers Junior to him in the I.P.S. cadre of the Punjab State were officiating in the senior scale therefore, the order of reversion made against the appellant on November 3, 1958 was in effect a reduction in rank within the meaning of Art. 311 2  of the Constitution for it operated as a forfeiture of his right, and inasmuch as the appellant was given noopportunity of showing cause against the said order of reversion, there was a violation of the provisions of Art. 311 of the Constitution.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the senior scale without any selection by the State Government, though numbermally we apprehend that an officer in the junior scale may expect to go

arguments.claim: Reversion involves penal consequences (loss of pay, seniority, future promotion) per Parshotam Lal Dhingra, thus reduction in rank by punishment attracting Art 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: Alternatively, the appellant has contended that on the principles laid down by this Court in Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India 1 , the order of reversion made against the appellant involved penal consequences and operated as a punishment against the -appellant both in the matter ,of his pay and seniority it has been contended that the order entailed loss of pay as well as loss of seniority and postponement of the appellants future chances of promotion therefore, although in form the Government had purported to exercise its right to revert the appellant to  1  1958 S.C.R. 828. his substantive rank, the order of reversion really amounted to a reduction in rank by way of punishment, irrespective of whether the appellant had a right to be appointed to a vacancy in the senior scale.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: er post he may be reverted after a trial in that post or for administrative reasons and such reversion does number amount to reduction in rank within

arguments.claim: Order of reversion was mala fide, improper, violates Arts 14 and 16.

anchor.surface_text: He has also raised a contention that the order of reversion was malafide, improper and against the provisions of Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: No absolute right to senior scale vacancy; appointment involves selection per r.4(2) IPS Pay Rules 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondents, the main contention has been that under the relevant rules the appellant had noabsolute right to be appointed to a vacancy in the senior scale as and when such vacancy occurred therein and nobody senior to the appellant was available for it. The stand taken on behalf of the respondents is that under r. 4 2  of the Indian Police Service  Pay  Rules, 1954 appointment to a post on the senior time-scale is not automatic, because such appointment involves a process of selection therefore, there was noforfeiture of any right of the appellant by the order of reversion made against him and the provisions of Art. 311 2  are not attracted to it.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the senior scale without any selection by the State Government, though numbermally we apprehend that an officer in the junior scale may expect to go

arguments.claim: Reversion not by way of punishment; after trial in higher post, not fit; unrelated to departmental enquiry; covered by Expl 4 r.3 AIS Discipline Rules.

anchor.surface_text: As to the alternative contention of the appellant the reply of the respondents has been that the order of reversion made against the appellant was not made by way of punishment. In their written statements, the respondents have stated that the order of reversion was not made as a measure of punishment or penalty, but was made because the appellant who was tried as officiating Superintendent of Police was not found fit and ripe enough for being entrusted with the duties and res- ponsibilities of a Superintendent of Police. It was further averred that the departmental enquiry instituted against the appellant had nothing to do with the order of reversion. The respondents relied on Explanation  4  to r. 3 of the All India Services  Discipline and Appeal  Rules, 1955, which says that the reversion to a lower post of a member of the service who is officiating in a higher post, after a trial in the higher post or for administrative reasons  such as the return of the permanent incumbent from leave or deputation, availability of a more suitable officer, and the like  does not amount to reduction in rank within the meaning of r. 3 which deals with penalties that may, for good and sufficient reasons, be im- posed on a member of the service.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: er post he may be reverted after a trial in that post or for administrative reasons and such reversion does number amount to reduction in rank within

arguments.claim: Reversion not mala fide or violating Art 14/16.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents have also denied that the order of reversion made against the appellant was malafide or improper or that it violated the fundamental rights guaranteed under Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Appellant had no right to officiating Superintendent post; reversion covered by Expl 4 r.3 AISDAR; not reduction in rank under Art 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: We may now briefly state the findings which the High Court has arrived at. The first finding of the High Court was that the appellant did not hold the officiating post of a Superintendent of Police as a matter of right and his case was covered by Explanation  4  referred to above therefore, the order of reversion did not amount to reduction in rank within the meaning of Art. 311 2  of the Constitution.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the senior scale without any selection by the State Government, though numbermally we apprehend that an officer in the junior scale may expect to go

arguments.claim: Reversion not by way of punishment; reasons for charge sheet different from reversion.

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, the High Court found that the reversion of the appellant to his substantive rank of Assistant Superintendent of Police was not by way of punishment and the reasons which led to the framing of a charge sheet against the appellant were not the reasons which prompted the order of reversion. Therefore, the order of reversion was not per se an order of punishment and did not inflict any stigma or stain upon the appellant, nor was the appellant debarred from future promotion to the senior scale.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: er post he may be reverted after a trial in that post or for administrative reasons and such reversion does number amount to reduction in rank within

arguments.claim: No automatic right to senior scale; appointment by selection per rules.

anchor.surface_text: We proceed now to consider the first point urged on behalf of the appellant, namely, whether he had a right to a vacancy in the senior scale as and when such a vacancy occurred, except a vacancy in the promotion quota... [detailed reasoning on rules]... We have therefore come to the conclusion that the first contention urged on behalf of the appellant that he has a right to go automatically into the senior scale is not correct and cannot be upheld.

arguments.claim: Reversion involves penal consequences per Dhingra test; by way of punishment, violates Art 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: We turn now to the alternative argument of the appellant that in any view of the matter his reversion involved penal consequences to him within the meaning of the rule laid down in Parshotam Lal Dhingras case 1 ... Our conclusion is that in the present case the appellant was reverted by way of punishment, but he was given noopportunity of showing cause against the action proposed to be taken against him. Therefore the order of reversion dated November 3, 1958 was in violation of the provisions of Art. 311 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Mudholkar J: IPS member has right to senior scale post by seniority, no selection needed.

anchor.surface_text: The main question, therefore, for consideration is whether the appellants reversion amounts to a punishment. The determination of this question would depend upon the answer to be found to another question and that is whether the appellant, by virtue of his appointment to the Indian Police Service had a right to be promoted to and to hold the post of Superintendent of Police... [detailed rules analysis]... In our opinion, the whole scheme of the rules indicates that a person borne on the junior scale of pay has a right to hold a post on the senior scale of pay depending upon the availability of a post and his seniority in the Junior scale of pay.

arguments.claim: Reversion is punishment as reduces rank and withholds promotion despite right and juniors promoted.

anchor.surface_text: Despite the fact that he holds a certain rank in the gradation list persons who also belong to the Indian Police Service and who were recruited to it subsequent to him have continued to hold or have been appointed to hold posts car- rying salary in the senior scale. This would itself indicate that the action taken against him was by way of penalty or punishment.

arguments.claim: Reversion mala fide: to facilitate enquiry instead of suspension.

anchor.surface_text: A perusal of the file thus shows that instead of suspending the appellant during the pendency of the enquiry against him which was expected to take considerable time to finish, resort was had to his reversion on the vague grounds that he was a problem child and an immature person... We are told that in the departmental enquiry held against the appellant, though he has been found remiss, the only punishment awarded to him was stoppage of one increment without prejudice to his future... In the circumstances we have no doubt in coming to the conclusion that the order of the Government is mala fide.

arguments.claim: Expl 4 to r.3 AISDAR does not apply; reversion not administrative trial or return of incumbent.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the view that the case of the appellant was covered by the aforesaid Explanation even though the reversion of the appellant was not caused by the return of the permanent incumbent from leave or deputation nor by the availability of a more suitable officer... Whether the reversion of the appellant in the present case was by way of punishment or penalty... In our view Explanation  4  to r. 3 shows clearly enough that a member of the Service cannot claim the right of officiating in a higher post merely by reason of his seniority...

holdings.text: A member of the Indian Police Service in the junior time-scale has no automatic right to appointment to a post in the senior time-scale merely by reason of seniority; such appointment requires selection by the appointing authority under r.4(2) and r.8 of the IPS Pay Rules, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: We proceed now to consider the first point urged on behalf of the appellant, namely, whether he had a right to a vacancy in the senior scale as and when such a vacancy occurred, except a vacancy in the promotion quota. It is perhaps necessary to explain here what the promotion quota means. Rule 9 of the

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interpretation of IPS Pay Rules r.4(2), r.8, Cadre Rules r.8, Seniority Rules r.6, and AIS Discipline Rules r.3 Expl.4 shows appointment necessary, no automatic transition; efficiency bar and separate scales indicate selection involved.

holdings.text: Explanation 4 to r.3 of the All India Services (Discipline and Appeal) Rules, 1955 does not apply to a reversion that is punitive in nature, even if not due to return of incumbent or administrative reasons.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the view that the case of the appellant was covered by the aforesaid Explanation even though the reversion of the appellant was not caused by the return of the permanent incumbent from leave or deputation nor

holdings.reasoning_summary: Expl.4 covers trial or admin reasons without punishment intent; here reversion linked to unsatisfactory conduct and enquiry, imposing penal consequences.

holdings.text: The appellant's reversion involved penal consequences (loss of pay beyond reversion, loss of seniority, postponement of future promotions) within the Parshotam Lal Dhingra test, amounting to reduction in rank by way of punishment in violation of Art. 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: We turn now to the alternative argument of the appellant that in any view of the matter his reversion involved penal consequences to him within the meaning of the rule laid down in Parshotam Lal Dhingras case 1 . Dealing with the question of

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of Dhingra test's second limb: personal file extracts show reversion due to unsatisfactory conduct to facilitate enquiry; juniors continued in senior scale; no opportunity to show cause given.

holdings.text: The order of reversion dated November 3, 1958 is quashed as violative of Art. 311 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly allow this appeal and quash the order of reversion passed against the appellant on November 3. 1958.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consequential to finding of violation of Art. 311(2); appeal allowed with costs.

holdings.text: A member of the Indian Police Service borne on the junior scale has a right to hold a post on the senior scale depending on availability of post and his seniority (Mudholkar J.).

anchor.surface_text: The main question, therefore, for consideration is whether the appellants reversion amounts to a punishment. The determination of this question would depend upon the answer to be found to another question and that is whether the appellant,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of IPS Cadre Rules, Pay Rules, Seniority Rules, Recruitment Rules indicates single cadre with right by seniority; no express selection for junior to senior transition unlike promotions from state service.

holdings.text: Reversion amounts to punishment as it reduces rank and withholds promotion despite right to senior scale post and while juniors officiate (Mudholkar J.).

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that persons junior to the appellant in the gradation list were either continued to officiate

holdings.reasoning_summary: Withholding promotion despite seniority and juniors holding senior posts indicates penalty; requires enquiry under Art. 311.

holdings.text: The reversion order was mala fide, resorted to facilitate departmental enquiry instead of suspension (Mudholkar J.).

anchor.surface_text: A perusal of the file thus shows that instead of suspending the appellant during the pendency of the enquiry against him

holdings.reasoning_summary: Personal file shows reversion to avoid long enquiry time, on vague grounds like 'problem child'; devious method instead of suspension; minor punishment later awarded.

precedents.citation: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India 1

anchor.surface_text: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India 1 , the order of reversion made against the appellant involved penal consequences and operated as a punishment against the -appellant both in the matter ,of his pay and seniority

precedents.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: principles on when reversion from officiating post to substantive rank amounts to reduction in rank by way of punishment even if no right to the post
precedents.cited_holding: The real test for determining whether the reduction in such cases is or is not by way of punishment is to find out if the order for the reduction also visits the servant with any penal consequences. Thus if the order entails or provides for the forfeiture of his pay or allowances or the loss of his seniority in his substantive rank or the stoppage or postponement of his future chances of promotion

anchor.surface_text: Parshotam Lal Dhingras case 1 . Dealing with the question of reduction in rank, Das C.J. speaking for the majority of the court in that case said A reduction in rank likewise may be by way of punishment or it may be an innocuous thing.

precedents.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: test for determining if reduction/reversion is by way of punishment

anchor.surface_text: Parshotam Lal Dhingras case 1 , that the motive operating on the mind of the Government may be irrelevant but it must also be remembered that in a case where Government has by contract or under the rules the right to reduce an officer in rank

precedents.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: motive irrelevant but penal consequences determine if punishment

precedents.citation: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India 1

anchor.surface_text: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India 1  that a Government servant acquires a right to hold a post only in three kinds of cases the first is when he is substantively appointed to a permanent post in Government service

precedents.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Government servant acquires right to post only if substantive, fixed term temporary, or quasi-permanent after 3 years

anchor.surface_text: Dhingras case 1 . In the case before us Mr. Wadhwa was not reverted for an administrative reason like the unavailability of posts but for a different reason which we will indicate while dealing with the second point raised by him.

precedents.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: reversion amounts to reduction in rank under Art. 311 if by way of punishment

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly allow this appeal and quash the order of reversion passed against the appellant on November 3. 1958. The appellant will be entitled to his companyts of this companyrt and the High Court.
